title: Cat. 26.2  Portrait of Stéphane Mallarmé, 1891, printed 1919
publication_title: Gauguin Paintings, Sculpture, and Graphic Works at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Portrait of Stéphane Mallarmé  
1891, printed 1919  
Etching, with drypoint and engraving, in brown-black ink, on cream laid Japanese paper; 183 × 145 mm (plate); 330 × 240 mm (sheet)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, the Albert H. Wolf Memorial Collection, 1935.46  
Guérin 14, Kornfeld 12 II/IV B,b  
For the verso, see fig. 26.2.1

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section provenance" id="provenance">Sold by Jean André Goriany (born 1893), New York and Lima, to the Art Institute of Chicago, 1935.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section exhibitions" id="exhibitions">New York, Wildenstein & Co., A Loan Exhibition of Paul Gauguin, for the Benefit of the New York Infirmary, Apr. 3–May 4, 1946, cat. 86.

Munich, Haus der Kunst, Paul Gauguin, Apr. 1–May 29, 1960, cat. 171.

Vienna, Österreichische Galerie im Oberen Belvedere, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, June 7–July 31, 1960, cat. 74.

(Richmond) Virginia Museum, Loïe Fuller: Magician of Light, Mar. 12–Apr. 22, 1979, cat. 38.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section references" id="references">Wildenstein & Co., A Loan Exhibition of Paul Gauguin, for the Benefit of the New York Infirmary, with an essay by Raymond Cogniat (Wildenstein & Co., 1946), p. 74, cat. 86.

Haus der Kunst, Paul Gauguin, with essays by Germain Bazin and Harold Joachim, exh. cat. (Ausstellungsleitung München e.V. Haus der Kunst, 1960), p. 30, cat. 171.

Oberes Belvedere, Paul Gauguin, 1848–1903, exh. cat. (Österreichische Galerie im Oberen Belvedere, 1960), p. 43, cat. 74.

Art Institute of Chicago, Gauguin Prints (Art Institute of Chicago, 1959), n.pag. (ill.).

Margaret Haile Fuller, Loïe Fuller: Magician of Light, exh. cat. (The Museum, 1979), p. 61, cat. 38.

Elizabeth Mongan, Eberhard W. Kornfeld, and Harold Joachim, Paul Gauguin: Catalogue Raisonné of His Prints, with assistance of Christine E. Stauffer (Galerie Kornfeld, 1988), p. 44, cat. 12.

Belinda Thomson, Gauguin (Thames & Hudson, 1987), p. 126, fig. 110 (ill.).

Britt Salvesen, Gauguin, in association with Douglas W. Druick and Peter Kort Zegers, Artists in Focus (Art Institute of Chicago/Abrams, 2001), pp. 39, 42, fig. 18.

Linda Goddard, “Hierarchies of the Senses in Symbolist Criticism,” in Aesthetic Rivalries: Word and Image in France, 1880–1926 (P. Lang, 2012), pp. 17–18, fig. 1.

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section other_documentation" id="other_documentation">Inscribed lower right, below image, in graphite: 64/79

Inscribed lower left, below image: [erased and illegible]

Collection stamp in oval, center, in brown ink: THE ART / INSTITUTE OF / CHICAGO

Inscribed lower right, in graphite: 35.46 / R 5694

</section><section epub:type="footnotes" id="footnotes">An edition of seventy-nine copies was printed posthumously in brown on Japanese paper, sixty of which were included in the 1919 edition by Charles Morice, Gauguin (H. Floury, 1919). The Art Institute’s copy is number 64/79.

</section><section id="figures">Cat. 26.2 Portrait of Stéphane Mallarmé, 1891, printed 1919.

fig. 26.2.1 Verso of Gauguin’s Portrait of Stéphane Mallarmé (1891, printed 1919). The Art Institute of Chicago, 1935.46.

</section>
